message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had an immediate popping sensation in his knee, and he cannot extend his right leg or flex his right thigh, which suggests a quadriceps tendon tear. Meniscal tear may cause pain and swelling, but it does not usually result in the inability to extend the leg or flex the thigh. Femoral fracture and avascular necrosis of the femur are unlikely based on the history provided.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The immediate popping sensation, inability to extend the right leg or flex the right thigh, and warm and swollen right knee are consistent with a Quadriceps tendon tear. The medications and medical history are not significant factors in this condition. A meniscal tear usually results in pain and swelling but the patient is unable to extend their leg or flex their thigh. A femoral fracture would result in severe debilitation and pain. Avascular necrosis of the femur is usually asymptomatic and does not result in immediate debilitation or pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to extend his right leg or flex his right thigh suggests a quadriceps tendon tear, which can cause severe pain and difficulty walking. The patient’s medical history of obesity and recent corticosteroid use may also contribute to this condition. Meniscal tear and femoral fracture may also cause knee pain, but the symptoms described by the patient are more consistent with a quadriceps tendon tear. Avascular necrosis of the femur is not a likely cause of acute knee pain and swelling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including swelling and inability to extend the right leg or flex the right thigh, strongly suggest a quadriceps tendon tear. The other options, such as meniscal tear or avascular necrosis, may cause pain in the knee but would not have the same restriction of movement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The immediate popping sensation and inability to flex the thigh suggests a quadriceps tendon tear. Meniscal tear may cause pain but not necessarily an inability to extend the leg or flex the thigh. Femoral fracture and avascular necrosis are less likely given the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe pain and inability to extend the right leg or flex the right thigh suggest a Quadriceps tendon tear. Obesity, diabetes, and corticosteroid use are all risk factors for tendon rupture. None of the other options match the symptoms and risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with severe pain, inability to stand or walk, and inability to extend the right leg or flex the right thigh, which are all signs of a Quadriceps tendon tear. Meniscal tear and avascular necrosis of the femur do not cause immediate severe pain and inability to stand or walk. Femoral fracture can cause immediate pain and inability to stand or walk, but it would be associated with more significant trauma. The patient's medical history suggests that he may have higher risk for tendon or ligament injuries due to obesity and systemic corticosteroid use for asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient reports an immediate popping sensation in his right knee, is unable to extend his right leg or flex his right thigh, and has warm and swollen right knee. These symptoms indicate a quadriceps tendon tear. Meniscal tear may cause locking or catching of the knee, but not the inability to extend the leg. Femoral fracture often causes the inability to bear weight on the affected leg. Avascular necrosis typically causes bone pain and limited joint movement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's inability to extend his right leg or flex his right thigh suggests a quadriceps tendon tear. A meniscal tear would not affect extension or flexion, while a femoral fracture or avascular necrosis of the femur would cause more global symptoms such as difficulty bearing weight or pain with range of motion. The patient's medical history also suggests an increased risk for tendon and ligament injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain and inability to extend the leg or flex the thigh suggests a quadriceps tendon tear. The patient’s medical history and recent use of corticosteroids may have contributed to the weakness of the tendon. Meniscal tear would have produced a different set of symptoms such as locking of the knee and catching sensations. Femoral fracture and avascular necrosis of the femur are less likely given the lack of trauma history and normal X-ray findings at this time.
